pull.title: test: Test p2sh-witness and bech32 in wallet_import_rescan
pull.body: This adds test coverage for segwit in the `wallet_import_rescan` test, among other cleanups.

events.body: Fixed linter by adding the false-positive to a whitelist 😬

<!--e57a25ab6845829454e8d69fc972939a-->

The following sections might be updated with supplementary metadata relevant to reviewers and maintainers.

<!--174a7506f384e20aa4161008e828411d-->
### Conflicts
Reviewers, this pull request conflicts with the following ones:

* [#16597](https://drahtbot.github.io/bitcoin_core_issue_redirect/r/16597.html) ([WIP] Travis: run full test suite on native macOS by Sjors)
* [#15845](https://drahtbot.github.io/bitcoin_core_issue_redirect/r/15845.html) (wallet: Fast rescan with BIP157 block filters by MarcoFalke)
* [#15257](https://drahtbot.github.io/bitcoin_core_issue_redirect/r/15257.html) (Scripts and tools: Bump flake8 to 3.7.8 by Empact)
* [#13728](https://drahtbot.github.io/bitcoin_core_issue_redirect/r/13728.html) (lint: Run the CI lint stage on mac by Empact)

If you consider this pull request important, please also help to review the conflicting pull requests. Ideally, start with the one that should be merged first.<!--2502f1a698b3751726fa55edcda76cd3-->

### Coverage

| Coverage  | Change ([pull 16465](https://drahtbot.github.io/reports/coverage/bitcoin/bitcoin/16465/total.coverage/index.html), ba118a39c84bb79e5ed12db0050ff18d1595544c) | Reference ([master](https://drahtbot.github.io/reports/coverage/bitcoin/bitcoin/master/total.coverage/index.html), e5fdda68c6d2313edb74443f0d1e6d2ce2d97f5e)   |
|-----------|-------------------------|--------------------|
| Lines     | +0.0337 %            | 89.2260 %        |
| Functions | -0.0157 %            | 82.1944 %        |
| Branches  | +0.0175 %            | 46.6152 %        |

<sup>Updated at: 2019-08-07T11:47:01.569823.</sup>

More dead code hits? https://gist.github.com/Sjors/e2704ff54fdc85b2b5833242a1d1e3e3

Tests pass on top of #16301.

> Tests pass on top of #16301 

Thanks, was about to test this.

@Sjors Regarding your posted gist: according to `lint-python-dead-code.sh` `vulture` should only look at files returned by `git ls-files`. Really weird that it checks `.git/logs/` and `depends/`. Files under these directories should never be returned by `git ls-files`, right?
A few nits inline. Also, in commit _test: Generate one block for each send in wallet_import_rescan_, can you add a motivation to the commit log. I can see what it's doing, but I don't understand why.

verification.payload:
tree c437c36c856d3a7f234b7353ac4771387878449c
parent fe001925f803ee9281c73da1265c401ba6a2b5ca
author MarcoFalke <falke.marco@gmail.com> 1556114906 -0400
committer MarcoFalke <falke.marco@gmail.com> 1565814157 -0400

test: Generate one block for each send in wallet_import_rescan

This ...
* ensures that enough coins are available/spendable, even when more
  variants are added
* ensures that all mempool txs are mined, even when more variants are
  added
* makes the test more specific to test that the confirmation height
  is properly reported and timestamps are correctly handled in the test
  logic
* prepares the test for a future, where blocks are skipped for rescan if
  they are deemed irrelevant by a filter (c.f. BIP157)

events.message:
test: Generate one block for each send in wallet_import_rescan

This ...
* ensures that enough coins are available/spendable, even when more
  variants are added
* ensures that all mempool txs are mined, even when more variants are
  added
* makes the test more specific to test that the confirmation height
  is properly reported and timestamps are correctly handled in the test
  logic
* prepares the test for a future, where blocks are skipped for rescan if
  they are deemed irrelevant by a filter (c.f. BIP157)

events.body:
> A few nits inline. Also, in commit test: Generate one block for each send in wallet_import_rescan, can you add a motivation to the commit log. I can see what it's doing, but I don't understand why.

Added a few bullet points why generating a block each makes sense.

Thanks for the review @jnewbery. I think I addressed all feedback
Looks good. Couple more comments inline.

events.message: lint: Add false positive to python dead code linter

events.body: Reworked the whitelist, as requested by @jnewbery

post-merge utACK fa3c6575cac5e3841797980fe60b8368ae579dba. Sorry for not getting to this. I looked a while ago but was thrown off by the first commit, because it seemed to be making the test slower and more complicated for no reason, but it's very well explained now, and in general all the new improvements and suggestions are really nice.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -143,21 +161,28 @@ def setup_network(self):
             connect_nodes(self.nodes[i], 0)
 
     def run_test(self):
+        self.random_gen = random.Random(123456)
         # Create one transaction on node 0 with a unique amount for
         # each possible type of wallet import RPC.
         for i, variant in enumerate(IMPORT_VARIANTS):
             variant.label = "label {} {}".format(i, variant)
-            variant.address = self.nodes[1].getaddressinfo(self.nodes[1].getnewaddress(variant.label))
+            variant.address = self.nodes[1].getaddressinfo(self.nodes[1].getnewaddress(
+                label=variant.label,
+                address_type=variant.address_type.value,
+            ))
             variant.key = self.nodes[1].dumpprivkey(variant.address["address"])
-            variant.initial_amount = 1 - (i + 1) / 64
+            variant.initial_amount = Decimal(str(self.random_gen.random())[:10])  # random amount with 8 decimal places
             variant.initial_txid = self.nodes[0].sendtoaddress(variant.address["address"], variant.initial_amount)
+            self.nodes[0].generate(1)  # Generate one block for each send
+            variant.confirmation_height = self.nodes[0].getblockcount()
+            variant.timestamp = self.nodes[0].getblockheader(self.nodes[0].getbestblockhash())["time"]
 
-        # Generate a block containing the initial transactions, then another
-        # block further in the future (past the rescan window).
-        self.nodes[0].generate(1)
+        # Genrate a block further in the future (past the rescan window).
comments.body: Typo introduced: 'Genrate' -> 'Generate'

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -143,21 +161,28 @@ def setup_network(self):
             connect_nodes(self.nodes[i], 0)
 
     def run_test(self):
+        self.random_gen = random.Random(123456)
comments.body: No need to reset the seed here. It should be left as set by the test_framework (where it can be set deterministically).

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -125,12 +143,12 @@ def skip_test_if_missing_module(self):
         self.skip_if_no_wallet()
 
     def setup_network(self):
-        extra_args = [["-addresstype=legacy"] for _ in range(self.num_nodes)]
+        self.extra_args = [[] for _ in range(self.num_nodes)]
comments.body: nit: I think `[[]] * self.num_nodes` is slightly clearer (and also matches L154 below)

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -143,21 +161,28 @@ def setup_network(self):
             connect_nodes(self.nodes[i], 0)
 
     def run_test(self):
+        self.random_gen = random.Random(123456)
         # Create one transaction on node 0 with a unique amount for
         # each possible type of wallet import RPC.
         for i, variant in enumerate(IMPORT_VARIANTS):
             variant.label = "label {} {}".format(i, variant)
-            variant.address = self.nodes[1].getaddressinfo(self.nodes[1].getnewaddress(variant.label))
+            variant.address = self.nodes[1].getaddressinfo(self.nodes[1].getnewaddress(
+                label=variant.label,
+                address_type=variant.address_type.value,
+            ))
             variant.key = self.nodes[1].dumpprivkey(variant.address["address"])
-            variant.initial_amount = 1 - (i + 1) / 64
+            variant.initial_amount = Decimal(str(self.random_gen.random())[:10])  # random amount with 8 decimal places
             variant.initial_txid = self.nodes[0].sendtoaddress(variant.address["address"], variant.initial_amount)
comments.body: This will fail if the value to send is too low. Because you set the seed, the 'randomly' picked number will not actually fail here, but if this test is changed (eg to support more address types) it could start failing here. I suggest you but a lower bound on the random amount.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -4,13 +4,22 @@
 # file COPYING or http://www.opensource.org/licenses/mit-license.php.
 """Encode and decode BASE58, P2PKH and P2SH addresses."""
 
+import enum
+
 from .script import hash256, hash160, sha256, CScript, OP_0
 from .util import hex_str_to_bytes
 
 from . import segwit_addr
 
 ADDRESS_BCRT1_UNSPENDABLE = 'bcrt1qqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqqq3xueyj'
 
+
+class AddressType(enum.Enum):
+    bech32 = 'bech32'
+    p2sh_segwit = 'p2sh-segwit'
+    legacy = 'legacy'
comments.body: nit: add a comment here that this refers to P2PKH (P2SH is also a legacy address type)

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,93 @@
+_.posix_path  # unused attribute (contrib/macdeploy/custom_dsstore.py:45)
comments.body: Please remove comments with line numbers (which are not stable and will not be updated when those files are changed), and deduplicate this list.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,93 @@
+_.posix_path  # unused attribute (contrib/macdeploy/custom_dsstore.py:45)
comments.body:
:+1: for moving these to one per line. I think you can keep the original `vulture` invocation by making this a list and then running:

`vulture --ignore-names=$(cat lint-python-dead-code-whitelist | tr '\n' ',')` or similar.

comments.body:
Can you explain how this is supposed to work? Be reminded that floating point has no fixed number of decimal places.

```
Decimal(round(random.random(), 8))
Decimal('0.5843940499999999982350118443719111382961273193359375')

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,93 @@

comments.body: I don't understand. Why add comments here that will be wrong almost instantly?

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -116,6 +134,14 @@ def check(self, txid=None, amount=None, confirmations=None):
 # Rescans start at the earliest block up to 2 hours before the key timestamp.
 TIMESTAMP_WINDOW = 2 * 60 * 60
 
+AMOUNT_DUST = Decimal('0.00000546')
+
+
+def get_rand_amount():
comments.body:
This returns `None` if the random value returned is less than `AMOUNT_DUST`.

Why not use `random.uniform(AMOUNT_DUST,1)` rather than define this function?

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -125,12 +151,12 @@ def skip_test_if_missing_module(self):
         self.skip_if_no_wallet()
 
     def setup_network(self):
-        extra_args = [["-addresstype=legacy"] for _ in range(self.num_nodes)]
+        self.extra_args = [[]] * self.num_nodes
comments.body: is changing this to `self.extra_args` necessary? Does that member get used again? (I think not, since the nodes are not restarted)

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -125,12 +151,12 @@ def skip_test_if_missing_module(self):
         self.skip_if_no_wallet()
 
     def setup_network(self):
-        extra_args = [["-addresstype=legacy"] for _ in range(self.num_nodes)]
+        self.extra_args = [[]] * self.num_nodes
comments.body: No, not necessary, but will make the code robust in case a restart is necessary.

+
+

comments.body: Switched to uniform

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,93 @@
+_.posix_path  # unused attribute (contrib/macdeploy/custom_dsstore.py:45)
comments.body:
Only the line number will be wrong. The rest should still be valid and might even be useful. I don't see a reason to manually fix the line number every time this file is autogenerated.

Edit: To obtain such a whitelist automatically, pass --make-whitelist to Vulture.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,93 @@
+_.posix_path  # unused attribute (contrib/macdeploy/custom_dsstore.py:45)
comments.body:
I don't get it. Every time a new function that triggers a false positive in vulture is added, this should be regenerated? That'll create a huge diff. How is that supposed to be reviewed?

In general, I don't think it's good practice to use the output of a tool to generate its own whitelist. The whitelist should be generated (and reviewed) by someone outside the tool declaring that these functions should be ignored.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -15,5 +15,5 @@ fi
 
 vulture \
     --min-confidence 60 \
-    --ignore-names "argtypes,connection_lost,connection_made,converter,data_received,daemon,errcheck,is_compressed,is_valid,verify_ecdsa,msg_generic,on_*,optionxform,restype,profile_with_perf" \
-    $(git ls-files -- "*.py" ":(exclude)contrib/" ":(exclude)test/functional/data/invalid_txs.py")
+    $(git rev-parse --show-toplevel) \
+    $(dirname "${BASH_SOURCE[0]}")/lint-python-dead-code-whitelist
comments.body: Won't this run `vulture` on the `lint-python-dead-code-whitelist` file? The intention was to use `lint-python-dead-code-whitelist` to build `--exclude`? :-)

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,45 @@
+BadInputOutpointIndex  # unused class (test/functional/data/invalid_txs.py)
comments.body:
Fascinating:

```
→ cat test/lint/lint-python-dead-code-whitelist | LC_ALL=en_US.UTF-8 sort
BadInputOutpointIndex  # unused class (test/functional/data/invalid_txs.py)
_.carbon_path  # unused attribute (contrib/macdeploy/custom_dsstore.py)
connection_lost  # unused function (test/functional/test_framework/mininode.py)
connection_made  # unused function (test/functional/test_framework/mininode.py)
[...]
→ cat test/lint/lint-python-dead-code-whitelist | LC_ALL=C sort
BadInputOutpointIndex  # unused class (test/functional/data/invalid_txs.py)
DuplicateInput  # unused class (test/functional/data/invalid_txs.py)
InvalidOPIFConstruction  # unused class (test/functional/data/invalid_txs.py)
NonexistentInput  # unused class (test/functional/data/invalid_txs.py)
OutputMissing  # unused class (test/functional/data/invalid_txs.py)
SizeTooSmall  # unused class (test/functional/data/invalid_txs.py)
SpendNegative  # unused class (test/functional/data/invalid_txs.py)
SpendTooMuch  # unused class (test/functional/data/invalid_txs.py)
TooManySigops  # unused class (test/functional/data/invalid_txs.py)
_.carbon_path  # unused attribute (contrib/macdeploy/custom_dsstore.py)
_.converter  # unused attribute (test/functional/test_framework/test_framework.py)
[...]
```

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -125,12 +143,12 @@ def skip_test_if_missing_module(self):
         self.skip_if_no_wallet()
 
     def setup_network(self):
-        extra_args = [["-addresstype=legacy"] for _ in range(self.num_nodes)]
+        self.extra_args = [[] for _ in range(self.num_nodes)]
comments.body: No big deal, but reason it was written the other way is so you could say args[1].append("something") without unintentionally adding "something" to args[0], [2], [3], and so on. Weirdness of list expressions in python.
